awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Robust-by-Design Networked Dynamical Systems: Bridging the Logic/Analog Divide
awd_abstract_narration:
Fragility and resiliency of future, highly-interconnected networked control system is a major concern for safety-critical applications such as autonomous vehicles and the energy generation/distribution grid. Failure events of such critical systems must be carefully studied, and systems redesigned to avoid them. The current state of the art involves time-consuming and inherently incomplete after-design simulations.  The aim of this project is to develop theoretical and computationally scalable techniques so that such systems can be robust-by-design. Our methodology can help design more resilient components and systems with a-priori safety guarantees.

We will develop a framework in which networked dynamic systems are analyzed by modeling interactions as event-triggered and/or stochastic couplings. Such dynamical couplings can be triggered by proximity, remote sensing or other pairwise mechanisms resulting in a state-dependent pattern of interactions for the overall system. Stability and robustness conditions will be given in terms of L2 and variance contractivity of systems, and algebraic properties of the state-dependent interaction graph. In contrast to Monte Carlo based methods, such conditions scale well with increasing system size. Synthesis methods for control algorithms with guaranteed performance in the presence of exogenous, adversarial, and system uncertainty will be developed using this framework. The education plan includes capstone design demonstrations and a new graduate level course in networked control systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mission-critical systems and infrastructure, whether for civilian, industry or military applications, have an enormous cost to society when they fail.  The main purpose of this project has been to more reliably design and accurately analyze the performance of these systems.  With this general motivation, the project research has focused on developing methodologies applicable to a wide range of applications, such as autonomous vehicles, power networks, gas distribution networks, and distributed robotics, to name a few.  In the project, methods have been constructed for analyzing and designing control systems in technological scenarios where physical processes interact with digital computing and communications hardware, and additionally in situations where control policies must have some degree of decentralization due to both the information measured, and the actuation, being distributed.  

A main component of the project has been developing direct policy optimization methods for switched systems, due to their various applications in reinforcement learning tasks.  Project research developments have included gradient based methods in this context for optimal and robust control of switched systems, which have been pursued in both a centralized and networked setting.  The global convergence of gradient methods for quadratic optimal control of discrete-time Markovian jump linear systems (MJLS) has been investigated; this involved determining optimization landscape characteristics of direct policy optimization for MJLS. The research has also developed techniques for designing static-state feedback controllers with quadratic performance metrics, and despite nonconvexity, it has been demonstrated that these gradient methods converge to the optimal policy at an exponential rate.  The work further brings new insights for understanding the performance of the policy gradient methods for switched systems.  In an explicitly networked formulation, the project has looked at developing similarly motivated algorithms, but in a derivative-free way considering a non-deterministic non-stochastic formulation with a worst-case performance metric.  This particular metric is non-smooth and non-convex with respect to the search space, and the project introduced and employed novel specialized subdifferentials to optimize it, and developed associated convergent algorithms. This approach contrasts with the traditional subgradient approach typically used to address such problems.  The work provides the first sample-complexity bounds for the performance of algorithms of this type.  

 Model-agnostic Meta-learning (MAML) and its variations have become central techniques for efficiently adapting to new tasks, such as those appearing in switched systems, by leveraging previous learning knowledge in areas like regression, classification, and reinforcement learning.  The convergence characteristics of MAML when applied to linear system quadratic optimal control (LQR) has been analyzed during the project, and new convergence guarantees have been established while maintaining the stability of the underlying dynamical system. Numerical experiments on systems with switched performance metrics have been completed illustrating the results. 

The project also has involved system identification research for switched linear systems.  In particular the least squares algorithm has been analyzed with the goal of providing high-probability finite-time theoretical guarantees. Two related scenarios have been considered: one in which the switching is i.i.d., and the other in which the switching occurs according to a Markov process. The research has led to concentration inequalities for the sample complexity.  To make the work accessbile to a broader community a number of numerical case studies have been completed. 

Real-time control methods for nonlinear systems that allow policies to simultaneously use a combination of data-based and model-based control have been developed during the project.  These methods address common scenarios in which a system model is available for the designer, but during run time there is additional available real-time data that can be used to refine the control strategy and improve performance.  This contrasts with methods that are either completely data-based,  or completely model-based; the main advantage of the project machinery is obtained in the gradient calculation.  Using this novel framework as the foundation, we have developed an experience-based algorithm for control of nonlinear systems in the presence of dynamical modeling errors, which adapts to real time data.  The launching point for the approach is a database seeded with many trajectories optimized under a reference estimate of real system dynamics. When executed on the real system, these trajectories will be suboptimal due to errors in the reference dynamics. The approach then leverages the aforementioned technique that combines both data and model, to refine the control policy.  Experiments on three benchmark dynamical systems have shown that the approach adapts quickly to online experience even when the reference model has significant errors. In these specific examples, the algorithm generates near-optimal solutions and is more sample efficient than well-known reinforcement learning techniques.
